sections.heading: Zwitterionic Nanohydrogel Grafted PVDF Membranes with
Comprehensive Antifouling Property and Superior Cycle
Yuzhang Zhu, Jinliang Wang, Feng Zhang, Shoujian Gao, Aqiang Wang, Wangxi Fang,
sections.text:
and Jian Jin*
Fouling caused by oil and other pollutants is one of the most serious challenges for membranes used for oil/water separation. Aiming at improving the comprehensive antifouling property of membranes and thus achieving long-term cyclic stability, it is reported in this work the design of a kind of zwitterionic nanosized hydrogels grafted poly(vinylidene fluoride) (PVDF) microfiltration membrane (ZNG-g-PVDF) with superior fouling-tolerant property for oil-in-water emulsion separation. Sulfobetaine zwitterionic nanohydrogels with the diameter of ≈50 nm are synthesized by an inverse microemulsion polymerization process. They are then grafted onto the surface of PVDF microfiltration membrane, endowing the membrane a superhydrophilic and nearly zero oil adhesion property. This ZNG-g-PVDF membrane exhibits great tolerance and resistance to salts pH, especially an excellent antifouling property to oil-in-water emulsions containing various pollutants such as surfactants, proteins, and natural organic materials (e.g., humic acid). The comprehensive antifouling property of the membrane gives rise to the cyclic stability of the membrane greatly improved. A nearly 100% recovery ratio of permeating flux is achieved during several cycles of oil-in-water emulsion filtration. The ZNG-g-PVDF membrane shows great potential in treating practical oily wastewater containing complicated components in the effluent.

such as coagulation and flotation,[2] gravity and skimming,[3] oil absorbance materials,[4] membrane technology has been acknowledged as a more effective approach to remove oil from water because of its high separation efficiency, low footprint, and low-energy consumption.[5] However, traditional membranes always suffer from serious fouling issue that causes fast decline of flux due to the adsorption of oil droplets on the surfaces and/or inner pores of membrane when used for oily wastewater treatment.[6] It results in great impedance on the development of membrane technology for practical oil/water separation. Improving the antifouling performance of membranes is thus crucial for oil-contaminated wastewater treatment.
Generally, membrane fouling can be mitigated by increasing the hydrophilicity of membranes.[7] Thus, significant efforts have been made to introduce the hydrophilic materials into the membrane via blending[8] or surface modification,[9] and thereby improving the antifouling performance of membranes. As for oil/water
separation, membrane surface with ultralow or even nearly zero oil-adhesive force is ideal to get promising anti-oil fouling, as well as high separation selectivity. To realize this purpose, hydrophilic materials with strong hydrated ability is promising to construct stable-repulsive boundary layer on the surface or inner pore of membrane. sections.heading: 1. Introduction
sections.text:
With the rapid growth of industries and global population, plenty of oily wastewater are generated in daily life.[1] Handling these oil contaminated wastewater to meet the stringent requirement of discharging these effluents is still a challenge. In comparison with the traditional separation technologies,
Adv. Funct. Mater. 2018, 1804121
1804121 (2 of 10) © 2018 WILEY-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA, Weinheim
water-retaining properties, and thus can trap plenty of water molecules to form repulsive layer to oil.[10] Combining with appropriate surface charge, nearly zero underwater oil adhesion force were achieved, even submerged to highly viscous crude oil.[10b] To date, various hydrophilic materials (including hydrogels) containing membranes with high water affinity and ultralow oil adhesion have been designed and investigated for oil/water separation, especially for crude oil/water separation.[11] However, most of reported work focused on treating pure oil/water mixture without consideration of more complicated objects. In fact, the components in real oil-contaminated effluents produced by industrial processes and daily life are rather complicated. Various pollutants, such as various salts, surfactants, proteins, and natural organic matters (NOM) usually coexist with oil droplets. This restricts the use of the currently reported superhydrophilic materials for practical application since the antifouling property of these materials is very likely weakened when faced with such a complex system. Therefore, developing membranes with comprehensive antifouling property towards various pollutants besides oil repellence are still highly required in consideration of practical oil/water separation. From the viewpoint of antifouling, zwitterionic polyelectrolytes have been recognized as one of the best materials and have been extensively studied to prevent adsorption of various foulants, such as proteins,[12] bacteria,[13] and NOM[14] on surfaces. Sulfobetaine is a typical representative among zwitterionic polyelectrolytes. The co-existence of cationic group (quaternary amine ion) and anionic groups (sulfonic group) in the sulfobetaine chain endows it with nearly neutral and good hydrated property, which has been supposed as the key point to exert its superior antifouling performance. More importantly, the hydrated behavior of sulfobetaine zwitterionic polyelectrolyte is not affected by environmental pH and common salts since sulfonic acid is a strong acid.[15]
Aiming at improving the comprehensive antifouling property of membranes and thus achieving long-term cyclic stability, we herein effectively combine the advantages of both hydrogel and zwitterionic compound and design a kind of zwitterionic nanohydrogels modified poly(vinylidene fluoride) (PVDF) microfiltration membrane (ZNG-g-PVDF) with superior fouling-tolerant property for oil/water emulsion separation. Nanohydrogels composed of sulfobetaine zwitterionic polyelectrolytes in the size of ≈ 50 nm were first synthesized and then grafted onto the surface of commercial PVDF microfiltration membrane. Nanohydrogels have higher special surface area which could provide more active sites for sufficient surface grafting. In addition, the small size of nanohydrogels could effectively weaken the steric hindrance during surface grafting. Thanks to the highly hydrated behavior of sulfobetaine zwitterionic polyelectrolytes and tough water-retaining ability of hydrogel, a repulsive boundary layer towards complicated pollutants are constructed, which endows the membrane with a highly hydrophilic property and nearly zero underwater oil adhesion. Meanwhile, the ZNG-g-PVDF exhibits excellent tolerance to different salts and wide range of pH. As for the separation of oil-in-water emulsion containing simultaneously various pollutants such as surfactant, protein, and humic acid, the membrane displays a high separation efficiency and a longterm cyclic stability with a nearly 100% recovery ratio.

sections.heading: 2.1. Preparation of ZNG-g-PVDF Membrane
sections.text:
The sulfobetaine ZNG-g-PVDF membranes were prepared by a simple surface grafting reaction as schematically shown in Figure 1a. In order to introduce surface anchoring sites for surface grafting, PVDF membrane was first immersed in NaOH solution for alkali treatment (Figure 1a). Alkali treatment induces the occurrence of dehydrofluorination of PVDF and results in the formation of active groups, such as hydroxyl and C=C double bond, on the surface of PVDF membrane (Scheme S1, Supporting Information).[16] The PVDF membrane is now named as alkali-treated PVDF (AT-PVDF) membrane. Through the following radical induced surface polymerization of acrylic acid, sufficient carboxyl groups were formed, which are used as for binding sulfobetaine nanohydrogels on membrane surface through the amide reaction between amine and carboxyl groups in the presence of N-(3-Dimethylaminopropyl)N′-ethylcarbodiimide (EDC)/N-hydroxysuccinimide (NHS).
The sulfobetaine zwitterionic nanohydrogels were produced via inverse microemulsion polymerization as schematically shown in Figure 1b. In the optically transparent inverse microemulsion solution (Figure 1c), water-swollen surfactant micelles with droplets size less than 1 µm are dispersed in the oil phase, in which free radical polymerization of zwitterionic [2-(Methacryloyloxy)ethyl]dimethyl-(3-sulfopropyl)ammonium hydroxide (DMAPS) monomer and cross-linker of N, N′-methylenebisacrylamide (MBA) was implemented. Nanohydrogels with average size around 54 nm were finally produced (Figure 1d). Transmission electron microscopy (TEM) images of these nanohydrogels displays porous spherical structure with particles size of tens of nanometer, agreeing with the result of dynamic light scattering (DLS, Figure S1, Supporting Information). Fourier transform infrared spectroscopy (FTIR) spectrum was used to determine the detailed components of the nanohydrogels (Figure S2, Supporting Information). Two strong characteristic peaks at 3448 and 1646 cm−1 are ascribed to the N–H stretching vibration and C=N stretching vibration of poly(allylamine hydrochloride) (PAH), respectively.[17] The three peaks at 1720, 1185, and 1045 cm−1 are assigned to the stretching vibration of C=O and the asymmetric and symmetric of SO3− groups in poly([2-(Methacryloyloxy)ethyl] dimethyl-(3-sulfopropyl)ammonium hydroxide) (PDMAPS), respectively.[18]
Figure 2 shows the optical photographs and corresponding top-view scanning electron microscopy (SEM) images of the membranes in different stages during nanohydrogels grafting process. Correspondingly, the membrane weight change during each step of preparation was recorded to test and verify the occurrence of chemical reaction. The weight of pristine PVDF membrane is used as a benchmark for comparison, which is defined as 100 wt% (Figure 2a). After alkali treatment, the membrane turns to be dark brown and its weight loss 15%. It confirms the occurrence of dehydrofluorination process (Figure 2b). The change of the color of PVDF membrane after alkali treatment is attributed to the formation of C=C bond during the dehydrofluorination process. After grafted with polyacrylic acid (PAA), the weight of the membrane slightly

increases to 86 wt% and the color of the membrane becomes shallower (Figure 2c). At last, the weight of ZNG-g-PVDF membrane further increases to 88 wt% (Figure 2d). All the membranes show similar surface morphology as shown in
Figure 2a1–d1, indicating the grafted polymer and nanohydrogels has almost no influence on membrane structure and morphology. The tensile strength of ZNG-g-PVDF membrane was also measured to evaluate the influence of dehydrofluorination on the mechanical strength of membrane. It shows that the stress of ZNG-g-PVDF is lower than that of pristine PVDF, indicating the alkali treatment has a negative effect on the mechanical strength of the membrane (Figure S3, Supporting Information).
The surface chemical composition of the membranes was identified by X-ray photoemission spectroscopy (XPS) measurement. The peaks of N1s, S1s, and S2p are clearly observed in the XPS survey spectrum of ZNG-g-PVDF membrane (Figure S4, Supporting Information), indicating the existence of PDMAPS on membrane surface.[9a] The peak of C1s could be deconvoluted into four peaks under consideration of the elements and the groups directly bonded to the carbon atoms (Figure 3). The characteristic peaks of PVDF centered at 290.4 eV (CF2) and 295.9 eV (CH2) are clearly obtained within all samples.[19] In the spectrum of pristine PVDF membrane, the two peaks centered at 284.8 and 287.4 eV are ascribed to C–H and carbon atoms in strong electron withdrawing environment (e.g., in ester group, amide group or bonded with electron withdrawing atoms such as N or O, signed with COO), respectively.[20] These peaks might be attributed to the additives in the commercial PVDF membrane. The C atom percentage of CF2 in terms of
total carbon atoms decreases from 36.3% in the case of pristine PVDF membrane to 35.2% in the case of AT-PVDF membrane as calculated according to the peak areas of C atoms. The C atom percentages of CF2 in the cases of PAA-g-PVDF membrane and ZNG-g-PVDF membrane are 28.2% and 18.1%, respectively, which are much lower than that of pristine PVDF membrane. Similar results are obtained for the C atom percentages of CH2, from 48.9% to 47.4%, 42.8%, and 36.1% corresponding to the pristine PVDF membrane, AT-PVDF membrane, PAA-g-PVDF membrane, and ZNG-g-PVDF membrane. In contrast, the C atom percentages of CH and COO increase from 11.1% to 12.5%, 18.8%, and 34.7% and from 3.6% to 4.7%, 10.2%, and 11.1%, respectively, as listed in Table 1 in detail, corresponding to the pristine PVDF membrane, AT-PVDF membrane, PAA-g-PVDF membrane, and ZNG-g-PVDF membrane. These results indicate that the nanohydrogels have been successfully anchored on the membrane surface.

sections.heading: 2.2. Characterization of Membrane Wettability
sections.text:
The wettability property of the membranes was evaluated by measuring the water contact angle (WCA) and the underwater oil contact angle (oil CA), as shown in Figure 4. The pristine PVDF membrane exhibits a hydrophobic property with WCA of ≈130° (Figure 4a). The photograph of water droplets dyed by Congo red on the surface of pristine PVDF membrane shows that the water droplets do not spread nearly on the membrane (bottom of Figure 4a). After alkali treatment, the hydrophilic property of the membrane is improved (Figure S5a,

Supporting Information). The initiated WCA of PAA-g-PVDF membrane is ≈85° and decreases to 0° within 5 s (Figure S5b, Supporting Information). The hydrophilic property of the membrane is further improved after anchoring the zwitterionic nanohydrogels on the membrane. The initiated WCA of ZNG-g-PVDF membrane is only 16° and quickly decreases to 0° within 3 s (Figure 4b), implying superhydrophilic property. The photographs of water droplets dyed with Cango red shows that the surface of ZNGg-PVDF membrane is completely wetted by water, leaving a pool of water and dye marks. Figure 4c is the underwater oil CAs of ZNG-g-PVDF membrane to various oils. All underwater oil CAs are around 160°, indicating excellent underwater superoleophobic property. A jet of isooctane (dyed by oil red) can easily bounce off the surface of ZNG-gPVDF membrane under DI water (Figure 4d), implying the extremely low adhesion to oil. Further test shows that the preloaded crude oil on the surface of ZNG-g-PVDF membrane can spontaneously escape from the membrane when immersing the membrane into water (Figure 4e). This result depicts the superior anti-oil-adhesion and selfcleaning property of the ZNG-g-PVDF membrane in an aqueous environment. Dynamic

underwater-oil-adhesion force measurement was performed to accurately evaluate the underwater-oil-adhesion force on the surface of ZNG-g-PVDF membrane and the result is shown in Figure 4f. The crude oil droplet is used as probe to contact the membrane surface. To ensure the sufficient contact between the oil droplet and the membrane surface, a load is applied on the oil droplet and then the oil droplet is lifted up from the membrane under water. As shown in Figure 4f, a smooth curve of adhesion force is obtained during the whole advancing and receding process. No obvious adhesion force (less than 1 µN) is detected and no droplet deformation is observed as oil droplet lifted off from the membrane surface (inset in Figure 4f). This
is mainly attributed to the superhydrophilic property and negatively charged surface of ZNG-g-PVDF (Figure S6, Supporting Information). Besides, the ZNG-g-PVDF membrane also exhibit excellent underwater anti-oil-adhesion property to other oils, such as cyclohexane, hexane, toluene, kerosene, and isooctane (Figure S7, Supporting Information).
The tolerance of ZNG-g-PVDF membrane to pH and salts were examined by testing the variation of water CA, underwater oil CA, and underwater oil-adhesion force of the membrane with changing the pH and salt (NaCl) concentration in water (Figure 5). As the water pH changes from 3 to 11, the water CA has little change and all are around 16° (Figure 5a) and quickly decrease to 0° within 3 s. Correspondingly, the underwater oil CA maintains around ≈160° with changing the pH of aqueous environment. Similar effects are also obtained in the case of salty solution. With increasing the salt concentration from 0.2 to 1 m in water, no obvious change of CA is observed (Figure 5b). These results indicate that ZNG-g-PVDF membrane is stable in a wide pH range and tolerant enough to high-concentration salty solution. The dynamic underwater-oiladhesion force of ZNG-g-PVDF membrane was also measured with changing the pH and salt concentration in water to further evaluate the tolerance of ZNG-g-PVDF membrane to pH and salt. As shown in Figure 5c, the underwater-oil-adhesion force curves are smooth, indicating no oil adhesion on the surface

As observed, no obvious adhesion force is detected in these cases. Similar results are also observed in other aqueous solutions containing Na2SO4, MgCl2, and CaCl2, respectively (Figure S8, Supporting Information). These results further confirm the excellent tolerance of ZNG-g-PVDF to pH and salt solution.

sections.heading: 2.3. Oil-in-water Emulsion Separation Performance
sections.text:
The membrane performance for emulsified oil/water separation was examined using various oil-in-water emulsions, namely isooctane-in-water emulsion, isooctane-in-water emulsion containing albumin bovine serum (BSA), isooctane-in-water emulsion containing humic acid, and Tween80-stabilized isooctane-in-water emulsion to permeate through ZNG-g-PVDF membrane individually. Taking Tween80-stabilized isooctanein-water emulsion as an example, Figure 6a and b shows optical photographs and optical microscopic images of the emulsion before and after permeated through ZNG-g-PVDF membrane. The emulsion is milky and the oil droplets are clearly observed in the optical microscopic image (Figure 6a). The size distribution of oil droplets in the emulsion is from hundreds nanometers to several micrometers as determined via DLS measurement (Figure 6c). After filtration, a transparent filtrate is obtained and there are no any oil droplets observed in the microscopic image (Figure 6b). The corresponding DLS curve displays only one signal around 10 nm (Figure 6d). This signal is ascribed to the micelles formed by dissolved surfactants but not oil droplets. It
confirms that oil droplets in the emulsion are effectively retained by the membrane. The exact oil content in the collected filtrate was measured by total organic carbon (TOC) analyzer. As shown in Figure S9 in the Supporting Information, the oil content in the collected filtrate is 19 ppm, indicating a separation efficiency as high as 99.8% as calculated based on the concentration of feed solution. The results of ZNG-g-PVDF membranes for separating surfactant-free, protein- and humic acid-contained emulsions are shown in Figure 6e–g. All the three feed solutions are muddy and non-transparent and become transparent after permeating through the membrane. The corresponding oil contents in the collected filtrates are 0.5, 7, and 6 ppm, respectively. The separation efficiency as calculated are all as high as 99.9%, indicating an outstanding separation performance of ZNG-gPVDF membrane for oil-in-water emulsions no matter what pollutants contained in the feed solution.
As for oil-in-water emulsion separation, membrane fouling is the main and tough problem to be faced. To evaluate the antifouling property of ZNG-g-PVDF membrane during a long-time filtration process, a lab-scale cross-flow equipment (Figure S10, Supporting Information) was used to monitor the variation of permeating flux during five cycles of filtration process within 10 h where the result of PAA-g-PVDF membrane was used as a control experiment. After one cycle filtration lasting for 2 h, simple hydraulic washing was performed to refresh the surface of the membrane and recover the permeating flux. As shown in Figure 7a, the permeating flux of ZNG-g-PVDF membrane is as high as 25 000 Lm−2 h−1 bar−1 as for isooctanein-water emulsion. The normalized permeating flux within one-cycle filtration slightly decreases within 2 h (Figure S11a, Supporting Information). The permeating flux after one cycle

The residual permeating flux is around 76% of the initiated flux after 2 h and the permeating flux can only be recovered partially after hydraulic washing, indicating the existence of an irreversible adsorption of oil droplets on membrane surface. As for Tween80-stabilized isooctane-in-water emulsion, the permeating flux of PAA-g-PVDF membrane dramatically declines to 25% of the initiated permeating flux (Figure S11b, Supporting Information), and the permeating flux cannot be recovered after hydraulic washing. In contrast, the permeating flux of ZNG-g-PVDF membrane gradually declines from ≈2250 to ≈1250 Lm−2 h−1 bar−1 within one-cycle filtration and it is completely recovered after hydraulic washing (Figure 7b). Additionally, the variation of permeating flux within five cycles is almost same, indicating the superior antifouling property of ZNG-gPVDF membrane for treating surfactant-stabilized oil-in-water emulsion.
As for isooctane-in-water emulsions containing BSA and humic acid, the ZNG-g-PVDF membrane still behaves similar cyclic stability (Figure 7c,d). The permeating flux decreases
from ≈2200 to ≈900 Lm−2 h−1 bar−1 during one cycle in the case of isooctane-in-water emulsions containing BSA. The permeating flux decreases from ≈1500 to ≈850 Lm−2 h−1 bar−1 during one cycle in the case of isooctanein-water emulsions containing humic acid. More importantly, they can be completely recovered after hydraulic washing. This result indicates that the ZNG-g-PVDF membrane possess excellent antifouling performance to not only oils but also to other pollutants such as protein and NOM. To present intuitively the superior antifouling property of ZNG-g-PVDF membrane, optical photographs of ZNG-g-PVDF membrane after permeated by Nile-red labeled various emulsions to finish the first cycle and then hydraulic washed were captured and shown in Figure 8 in comparison with the PAA-g-PVDF membrane. It is known that Nile-red emits red light under UV light irradiation. Therefore, we can tell by the color of the membrane whether Nile-red remains on the membrane or not. It can be seen that the surface of ZNG-g-PVDF membrane is rather clean and no any color of Nile-red, indicating no any detectable residues on membrane surface. In contrast, heavy red colors in the form of circles are clearly observed where the feed solutions are filtered. It indicates that PAA-g-PVDF membranes are seriously fouled by the four kinds of emulsions. Since luminescence is a very sensitive signal to detect the existence of fluorescent material, these results further confirm that the ZNG-g-PVDF membrane possess superior and comprehensive antifouling property
to not only oils but also various foulants those tend to cause membrane fouling usually.

sections.heading: 3. Conclusions
sections.text:
In this work, a ZNG-g-PVDF membrane with superior comprehensive antifouling performance for effective separation of various oil-in-water emulsions has been successfully fabricated via a simple surface grafting approach. The strong hydrated behavior combined with the water retaining ability of zwitterionic nanohydrogel endows the PVDF membrane with superhydrophilic/underwater superoleophobic property and ultralow underwater crude oil-adhesion force, even under saline environment and aqueous solution in a wide range of pH. When separating oil-in-water emulsions containing various foulants such as BSA and humic acid, the membrane still exhibited superior antifouling performance. The recovery of permeating flux as high as nearly 100% after several cycle filtration within 10 h. The superior cycle stability indicates the unprecedented comprehensive fouling-resistant ability of ZNG-g-PVDF membrane. Thanks to the simple preparation process of zwitterionic

sections.heading: 4. Experimental Section
sections.text:
Materials: PVDF microfiltration membrane with average pore size of 0.22 µm was commercially obtained from Yibo Filtration Equipment Ltd. Co. (Haining, Zhejiang Province China). The monomers of acrylic acid (99%), DMAPS (95%) and AH (98%) were purchased from Sigma
without further purification. MBA (97%) was purchased from Alfa. The initiator, azodiisobutyronitrile (AIBN, 99%), was obtained from Aladdin Chemistry Co. Ltd. (Shanghai, China). MES (99%) and EDC∙HCl (98%) were purchased from Aladdin Chemistry Co. Ltd. (Shanghai, China). NHS (98%) purchased from J&K Scientific Ltd. (Beijing, China). Other chemicals used in this work were all purchased from Sinopharm Chemical Reagent Co., Ltd and used as received.
Preparation of Sulfobetaine Zwitterionic Nanohydrogels: Sulfobetaine zwitterionic nanohydrogels were synthesized via inverse microemulsion polymerization of DMAPS, AH, and MBA. The detailed procedure is as follows: Tween 80 (4.26 g), Span 80 (4.92 g), and AIBN (24 mg) were first dissolved in 120 mL hexane equipped in a 250 mL three-neck

Change of permeating flux and flux recovery as separating a) surfactant free oil-in-water emulsion, b) surfactant-stabilized oil-in-water emulsion, c) surfactant-free oil-in-water emulsion with BSA in water, and d) surfactant-free oil-in-water emulsion with Humic acid in water over five cycles.

flask. Then an aqueous solution containing DMAPS (586.6 mg, 2.1 mmol), AH (84.2 mg, 0.9 mmol), MBA (13.8 mg), and Milli-Q water (1.5 ml) was added into the above hexane solution under stirring. After vigorous stirring and sonication for 30 min, the solution was purged with nitrogen for 30 min to remove dissolved oxygen, and then kept at 40 °C with magnetic stirring and protected under nitrogen atmosphere to polymerize for 24 h. 120 mL of tetrahydrofuran (THF) was then added into the reaction solution and stirred for 12 h to thoroughly break the microemulsion. The mixture was centrifuged for 15 min at 4500 rpm and the supernatant was discarded. The obtained precipitate was washed three times with 60 mL THF to remove the unreacted monomers. The obtained nanohydrogels were finally resuspended in 60 mL phosphate buffer saline (PBS) solution for use.
Preparation of PAA-g-PVDF Membrane: In a typical procedure, commercial PVDF membranes were soaked with ethanol and pure water in order. Then, the pure water soaked PVDF membranes were treated with 2 mol l−1 NaOH solution for 12 h under room temperature and rinsed with pure water. These AT-PVDF membranes were immersed in 100 mL aqueous solution, in which 5 mL acrylic acid monomer was added. After bubbling with N2 for 30 min, 1 g NaHSO3 and 1 g (NH4)2S2O8 were added into the aqueous solution. Then, the mixture was placed in a shaking incubator with a speed of 120 rpm at 60 °C. After 6 h, the membrane was taken out of the reaction solution and washed with DI water for several times to remove the unreacted monomers and the adsorption of PAA and stored in water for further use.
Preparation of ZNG-g-PVDF Membranes: Sulfobetaine ZNG-g-PVDF membranes were obtained by a simple surface reaction in the presence of EDC/NHS. The detailed procedure was as follows: PAA-g-PVDF membrane was first immersed into a 10 × 10−3 m MES buffer solution containing 2 × 10−3 m EDC∙HCl and 5 × 10−3 m NHS for 1 h. Then, the membrane was transferred into 5 g l−1 nanohydrogels suspension buffered with PBS for 24 h at room temperature. The obtained membrane was thoroughly rinsed with PBS buffer to remove adsorbed nanohydrogels and stored in water.
Characterization: DLS measurement was operated on a Malven Zen 3600. TEM images were obtained from a TEM (Tecnai G2 F20 S-Twin). SEM was employed on a field-emission SEM (Hitachi S4800, Japan). XPS was conducted by a Thermo Fisher Scientific ESCALAB 250Xi X-Ray photoelectron spectrometer. The dynamic WCA and underwater oil CA were measured on an OCA20 machine (Data-Physics, Germany) at ambient temperature. The dynamic underwater oil adhesion was conducted by using a self-constructed ring on OCA20. Oil content in filtrate was determined by Aurora 1030w O-I-Analytical TOC. Optical images were photographed using Canon EOS 50D.
Oil-in-water Emulsion Separation: Oil-in-water emulsion separation was carried out on a lab-scale cross-flow filtration equipment with membrane effective filtration area of 4.5 cm2. A series of isooctane-in-water emulsion containing surfactant, protein, and humic acid, respectively, were used as feed solutions to evaluate the separation efficiency and antifouling performance of membranes. To prepare surfactant-free oil-in-water emulsion, 15 mL isooctane was added into 1500 mL pure water under vigorous mechanical stirring for 30 min. The oil-in-water emulsion containing protein was prepared by adding BSA (1.5 g) into the isooctanein-water emulsion. The oil-in-water emulsion containing humic acid was prepared by adding humic acid (0.3 g) into isooctane-in-water emulsion. The surfactant-stabilized isooctane-in-water emulsion was prepared by adding 0.3 g Tween80 and 15 mL isooctane into 1500 mL pure water under vigorous mechanical stirring. All of the filtration experiments were conducted under 0.1 bar. The permeating flux of membranes could be calculated by using the following equation:
= ∆∆ ∆eff J V
A t P where ΔV is the volume of filtrate that permeated across the membrane in a predetermined time Δt during the test, Aeff is the effective membrane surface area, and ΔP is the trans-membrane pressure. The oil contents of filtrates were measured by TOC.
To evaluate the antifouling property of the membranes, the variation of permeating flux of the membranes with respect to filtration time during every cycle of isooctane-in-water emulsion separation was recorded. After filtration of oil-in-water emulsion, the membrane was washed by pure water and the next cycle of filtration was then conducted.

metadata.abstractText: Fouling caused by oil and other pollutants is one of the most serious challenges for membranes used for oil/water separation. Aiming at improving the comprehensive antifouling property of membranes and thus achieving long-term cyclic stability, it is reported in this work the design of a kind of zwitterionic nanosized hydrogels grafted poly(vinylidene fluoride) (PVDF) microfiltration membrane (ZNG-g-PVDF) with superior fouling-tolerant property for oil-in-water emulsion separation. Sulfobetaine zwitterionic nanohydrogels with the diameter of ≈50 nm are synthesized by an inverse microemulsion polymerization process. They are then grafted onto the surface of PVDF microfiltration membrane, endowing the membrane a superhydrophilic and nearly zero oil adhesion property. This ZNG-g-PVDF membrane exhibits great tolerance and resistance to salts pH, especially an excellent antifouling property to oil-in-water emulsions containing various pollutants such as surfactants, proteins, and natural organic materials (e.g., humic acid). The comprehensive antifouling property of the membrane gives rise to the cyclic stability of the membrane greatly improved. A nearly 100% recovery ratio of permeating flux is achieved during several cycles of oil-in-water emulsion filtration. The ZNG-g-PVDF membrane shows great potential in treating practical oily wastewater containing complicated components in the effluent.
